It may be Vladimir Putin’s war and strategy, but the ground operations are being coordinated by Russian generals on the frontlines, and they are every bit as culpable as their commander in the Kremlin.
Most likely, the targeting is done to inflict terror among the population, create massive refugee displacements, and draw frontline Ukrainian solders off the battlefield to assist civilians.
With today’s computers, advanced weapons and precision munitions, it is rare for any artillery unit to miss its target by a significant degree and even rarer for an error to be repeated.
While the generals may delegate authority for technical details, they are responsible for the tactical prosecution of the war, imposing restrictions such as no-fire zones.
They are also responsible for establishing collateral-damage guidelines to ensure that prohibited targets aren’t incidentally struck when an authorized target is engaged.
The bulk of the damage to Ukraine’s towns and cities is being done by munitions that fall from the sky: artillery, rockets and missiles fired far from the front lines.
It takes a willing suspension of disbelief to suggest that generals conducting operations today in Ukraine are unaware of the destruction their weapons are causing.
Every soldier who has ever pulled a lanyard or launched a missile is watching Russia’s total disregard for technical and tactical control in Ukraine with disgust.
Some may argue that the generals are too far removed or too high in the chain of command to bear responsibility for events on the ground.
U.S. artillery commanders have lawyers who carefully review battle plans to ensure they meet long-established rules of land warfare.
Thus any suggestion that the devastation in Ukraine is the result of poor training, outdated equipment or soldier fatigue is absurd.
